text: what makes a diamond priceless the
generally held belief is that diamonds
are expensive because they are
incredibly rare and they have some
intrinsic value but both of these
assumptions when viewed carefully
through an untainted eyepiece turn out
to be as fake as a pasted necklace a
diamond is nothing more than an
allotrope of carbon as is the graphite
in a pencil they are formed at
considerable depth below the earth's
surface
unlike to be cooked at high pressure at
a relatively low temperature like
sprouts they are brought to the surface
by volcanic eruptions and then promptly
by which I mean over several hundreds of
thousands of years redistributed and
buried again by the action of water wind
and what-have-you mining diamonds is
certainly tricky finding a one carat
diamond suitable for an engagement ring
will require you to sift through 250
tons of all but that is a gem a big posh
diamond that can be cut unpolished and
used as jewelry in truth most diamonds
are used industrially because diamond is
the hardest known naturally occurring
material it's excellent for coating and
tipping a variety of cutting grinding
and polishing tools 80% of diamonds
mined are used in this way and four
times that amount is produced
synthetically that's 500 million carats
a year 100 tons of diamond some of it in
your local hardware shop so diamonds are
not that rare after all and their
intrinsic value is merely that they're
harder than nails but what about gems
those cut and polished monsters that
hang provocatively in the cleavages of
Kim Kardashian and Co the beauty of gems
was first appreciated in India about
4000 years ago the Greeks and Romans
liked a bit of ice as well but elsewhere
diamonds didn't really catch on until
the late 19th century and up until then
were considered no
valuable than any other opaque or
translucent precious stone in the 19th
century however diamond prospecting on
an industrial scale began under the
British in what is now South Africa
according to basic economic theory that
should have reduced the value of
diamonds because they became
oversupplied but that didn't happen
because the number and price of diamonds
was controlled by syndicates in London
that came to agreement with the mining
companies cynics will argue that gem
diamonds are really nothing more than a
byproduct of the mining of diamonds for
industrial use and that there really
isn't any shortage of them at all it's
just being made to look that way and
what's more any brokenhearted man who
has had to return a diamond ring to a
jewelry shop will discover that the
profit margin on diamonds is at least as
high as it is for other so-called luxury
goods and unlike gold silver titanium or
even frozen orange juice there is no
fixed commodity price for diamonds
advertising has helped to maintain the
illusion that a diamond is somehow
permanent and priceless the slogan a
diamond is forever was created on behalf
of De Beers in 1948 and that along with
a bit of strategic Hollywood product
placement helped to convince everybody
so what makes a diamond priceless
basically merely that we all agree that
it is I'm very impressed that you kept
watching all the way to the end of that
explanation of why a diamond is
priceless and there's more if you'd like
to see and hear more why not subscribe
you just click on the button there
